benchmark_details.name: EMBER (Epistemic Marker Benchmark for Evaluator Robustness)
benchmark_details.overview: EMBER is a benchmark designed to assess the robustness of LLM-judges to epistemic markers in both single and pairwise evaluation settings, focusing on how these markers influence the judging performance of LLMs.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the robustness of LLM-judges against epistemic markers and assess how these markers affect their judgment on model-generated outputs.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The study focuses on two specific evaluation tasks, leaving other potential influences of epistemic markers across various tasks unexplored.

data.source: The EVOUNA dataset (Wang et al., 2024) for question-answering and MIXINSTRUCT (Jiang et al., 2023) for instruction-following.
data.size: 2,000 instances for EMBER QA and 823 instances for EMBER IF
data.annotation: Manually annotated by human evaluators after augmentation with epistemic markers.

methodology.calculation: Accuracy is defined as the match rate between LLM-judges and ground-truth labels. VSR indicates the percentage of samples that changed verdicts due to the presence of epistemic markers.
methodology.interpretation: Ideally, a robust LLM-judge should demonstrate zero changes in verdicts due to epistemic markers.
methodology.baseline_results: Results from five LLM-judges (GPT-3.5-turbo, GPT-4-turbo, GPT-4o, Llama-3-8B-Instruct, Llama-3-70B-Instruct) indicate biases against epistemic markers, particularly weakeners, affecting evaluation accuracy.
methodology.validation: Human evaluators assessed the correctness of model outputs augmented with epistemic markers to ensure validity.
